description: An Olympic runner on the power of positive thinking, loving “Lucy” and caffeinated nostalgia.
title: Opinion | Brenda Martinez
title_page: Opinion | Brenda Martinez - The New York Times
text:
Brenda Martinez is a track and field athlete specializing in middle distances who is competing in the 1,500 meters at the Rio Olympics.
READING Some of the books I read overlap, like “The Happiness Advantage” by Shawn Achor and “The One Thing” by Gary Keller and Jay Papasan. I like books that teach you to be positive. Your mind is your most powerful tool in reaching your potential and handling adversity. My primary event is the 800 meters, and I got clipped from behind coming off the final turn in the Olympic trials and then I was completely out of the race. I was distraught, but then I said to my husband, who is also my coach, “Let’s go make that 1,500 meter team.” I feel like reading positive psychology books and the examples they give of people who have overcome things maybe helped me step up and make the team.
LISTENING I don’t listen to music when I run because I don’t want to be dependent on music. I like to be aware of what’s going on, like I want to hear my footsteps to tell if I’m light on my feet. But when I’m not running, I like Selena because I remember dancing to her music when I was in third grade with my friend who lived across the street. I was shy but I would dance to Selena. And I like Lana del Rey. I know her lyrics can be a little dark but I love her voice. On my alarm clock I have it so I always wake up to Izzy’s “Somewhere Over the Rainbow.”
WATCHING I have the full set of the “I Love Lucy” series and I travel with them. My favorite one is the Vitameatavegamin episode. And I watch my four dogs — Rainy, Bolt, Chase and Peanut — and my cat, Boots. They can be pretty entertaining. On YouTube, I’ve been watching D.I.Y. home improvement videos because we bought a duplex near where we live in Big Bear, California, that needs a lot of work. I want to make it a daily rental on something like Airbnb. I feel like I’d make more money that way instead of renting it longer term. My plan is to have it paid off in eight to 10 years.
